mission.title: Our Mission

We believe that a diagnosis is just the beginning of a different, beautiful journey. We work tirelessly to erase stigma, provide medical resources, and build a community where no one feels alone.

WhatIsSBPage.title: Understanding Spina Bifida
WhatIsSBPage.intro: Spina Bifida is a neural tube defect that occurs during the first month of pregnancy. It is one of the most common birth defects affecting the spine and spinal cord.

prevention.title: Prevention & Folic Acid
prevention.text: Scientific research shows that up to 70% of Spina Bifida cases can be prevented if women take 400mcg of Folic Acid daily, starting at least one month before conception and throughout the first trimester.

occulta.desc: The 'hidden' form. There is typically a small gap in the spine but no opening or sac on the back. Most people live healthy lives without ever knowing.

meningocele.desc: A sac of fluid comes through an opening in the babyâ€™s back, but the spinal cord is not in this sac. Damage is usually minimal.

myelomeningocele.desc: The most complex form. A sac containing parts of the spinal cord and nerves comes through an opening. This causes moderate to severe disabilities.

lipomyelomeningocele.desc: A form of Spina Bifida where a fatty mass is attached to the spinal cord. It can cause progressive nerve damage if not managed.

myths.title: Common Myths
myths.item: Myth: It is hereditary or a curse. Fact: It is a combination of genetic and environmental factors. It is not anyone's 'fault'.

diagnosis.title: How is it Diagnosed?
diagnosis.prenatal: Most cases are detected during pregnancy through blood tests (AFP) and detailed ultrasounds. In some cases, fetal surgery can be performed to improve outcomes.
diagnosis.postnatal: After birth, MRI or CT scans are used to get a clear picture of the spine and brain structure.

treatment.title: Treatment & Management
treatment.surgery: Surgery to close the spine is usually performed within 48 hours of birth. Some babies may also require a 'shunt' to manage fluid on the brain (hydrocephalus).
treatment.multidisciplinary: Care involves a team: neurosurgeons, urologists, orthopedic surgeons, and physical therapists.

management.title: Critical Care & Management
management.intro: Living with Spina Bifida requires lifelong vigilance in several key areas to ensure the best quality of life.

kidneyInfection.title: Protecting Kidneys from Infection
kidneyInfection.text: Preserving kidney function and staying vigilant against infections, especially UTIs, is a top priority.

orthopedic.title: Orthopedic Check-ups
orthopedic.text: Regular orthopedic monitoring is essential for maintaining mobility and managing spinal issues.

rehab.title: Ongoing Rehabilitation
rehab.text: Physical therapy and rehabilitation must be a consistent, lifelong part of the care routine.

psychology.title: Psychological Support
psychology.text: Mental health support for both the individual and their family is vital for emotional well-being and adaptation.

LivingWithPage.title: Life with Spina Bifida
LivingWithPage.intro: Every stage of life has its unique challenges and beautiful victories. We are with you on every step.

child.title: Childhood
child.desc: Early intervention is key. We support families with kindergarten integration, finding the right wheelchair, and establishing early physio routines.

teen.title: Adolescence
teen.desc: Navigating social life and body image during teenage years. We run confidence-building workshops and peer support groups.

adult.title: Adulthood
adult.desc: Advocating for independent living, university accessibility, and employment rights for adults with Spina Bifida.

philosophy.title: A Life Full of Possibilities
philosophy.text: "Spina Bifida is part of who you are, but it doesn't define who you will become. From para-athletics to academic excellence, our community members are proving every day that there are no limits to what can be achieved."
